jNetDev
Class jND_CaptureSession

java.lang.Object
  jNetDev.jND_CaptureSession

public class jND_CaptureSession
extends java.lang.Object

jND_CaptureSession
A class to enable the capturing of packets. This class allows one to create a capture session, which may be started and stopped. When started, the capture process proceeds in a separate thread (see jND_CaptureThread).

The constructors set up the session and packets are captured when the start method is called. Once started, capturing proceeds until the stop method is called.

Another thread may obtain packets by querying and accessing the packet queue (jND_PacketQueue), which is obtained via the getPacketQueue method.

The calling code must specify a NIC (network interface card) to use for the capture. A list of available NICs may be obtained by via the jND_NIC class.

There is much to this class, including installing capture filters and capturing to a file. Read through the methods for details.

SPECIAL NOTE: When a capture session is created, the underlying pcap library is called to open a capture descriptor. The memory inherent in this is NEVER released unless you call the dispose() method. It is the programmer's responsibility to call dispose() when s/he is done with a Capture Session.

Constructor Detail

jND_CaptureSession

public jND_CaptureSession()
Default constructor. This is disallowed and will result in throwing and exception. We need a NIC and the promiscuous flag as a minimum to start a capture session.

jND_CaptureSession

public jND_CaptureSession(jND_NIC nic,
                          int snaplen,
                          boolean promisc,
                          int to_ms)
Creates a new capture session. No filter is attached to this session at the outset. Use setFilter to apply a filter. Packet capturing does not begin until the start method is called.

Parameters:
nic - a jND_NIC object describing the nic on which the capture will be made.
snaplen - the snapshot length. This amounts the length of the buffer for capturing.
promisc - true if the capture is to be done in promiscuous mode, false otherwise.
to_ms - timeout to use when capturing. This is expressed in milliseconds.

jND_CaptureSession

public jND_CaptureSession(jND_NIC nic,
                          boolean promisc)
Creates a new capture session. This is equivalent to jND_CaptureSession(nic, 1500, promisc, 1000)

Parameters:
nic - a jND_NIC object describing the nic on which the capture will be made.
promisc - true if the capture is to be done in promiscuous mode, false otherwise.

jND_CaptureSession

public jND_CaptureSession(java.lang.String file)
Creates a new capture session. This session will read saved packets from the provided capture file, until EOF, when the capture will automatically stop. This is not a live capture, but a capture of saved packets from a tcpdump file.

Parameters:
file - a file containing saved packets (saved in tcpdump format).
Method Detail

getThread

public java.lang.Thread getThread()
Get underlying thread

getDelayedDispose

public boolean getDelayedDispose()
Get delayed dispose state. If we dispose of a capture when the capture thread is runing, this is actually delayed until a SECOND stop, called from the thread, when it completes.

dispose

public void dispose()
Dispose of a capture session. This also closes any open dump sessions and destroys any compiled filters. After calling dispose, the capture session can no longer be used for capturing packets. This is more drastic than stop(). After calling stop(), the session may be restarted with start();

closeDumpFile

public void closeDumpFile()
Packets can be saved to a dump file. See openDumpFile and dumpPacket for more information. This closes an open dump file.

dumpPacket

public void dumpPacket(byte[] pkt)
Dumps one packet to an already open dumpfile.

Parameters:
pkt - - the packet to dump.

captureID

public int captureID()
Obtains the ID of this capture session.

Returns:
the capture ID of the session. This is an integer and has no meaning other than to differentiate between different sessions.

pcap_d

public byte[] pcap_d()
Obtains the pcap descriptor of this capture session.

Returns:
the pcap descriptor of the session.

inUseStatus

public int inUseStatus()
Obtains the status of this capture session. If jND_NONE is returned, the capture session is not in use. If jND_LIVE is returned, this is a live capture session, capturing packets from a NIC. If jND_OFFLINE is returned, this is an OFFLINE capture, which reads packets from a previously created dump file. jND_NONE, jND_LIVE and jND_OFFLINE are defined when jND_CaptureSession.h is included.

Returns:
the capture mode: one of jND_NONE, jND_LIVE or jND_OFFLINE.

captureStatus

public boolean captureStatus()
Obtains the capturing state of this capture session.

Returns:
the capture state ... true if a capture is in progress, false otherwise

captureStatus

public void captureStatus(boolean status)
Sets the status of this capture session. If status == true this means the the session is NOT capturing. If status == false then this means that the session IS capturing.

Parameters:
status - - the new status (capturing or note)

filter

public java.lang.String filter()
Obtains the current filter String for this session.

Returns:
a char string which is the currently installed filter. This is the empty string if no filter is installed.

packetQueue

public jND_PacketQueue packetQueue()
Obtains the queue of packets associated with this capture session. As a capture proceeds, it stores packets in this queue. The thread wishing to examine or process the packets must retrieve them from this queue.

Returns:
a queue of captured packets

openDumpFile

public void openDumpFile(java.lang.String fname)
Opens a dump file for saving packets. Packets are saved to the file with the dumpPacket method.

Parameters:
fname - - the name of the dump file

filter

public void filter(java.lang.String filterStr,
                   boolean optimize,
                   jND_BYTE4 netmask)
Sets the filter for the capture session. It is OK to set the filter while the Capture Session is capturing. This method expects the netmask (below) to be an int. The netmask is necessary for some filter strings. For details on filter strings, see the documentation of capture filters for tcpdump.

Parameters:
filterStr - a char string describing the filter using the syntax for tcpdump.
optimize - should the filter be optimized of not?
netmask - the netmask used by the filter. Some filter elements require this, others do not. Generally, those that involve IP addresses are those that use the netmask. NOTE: The netmask for a nic can be obtained from the associated jND_NIC object.

filter

public void filter(java.lang.String filterStr,
                   boolean optimize,
                   jND_IPv4Address inmask)
Sets the filter for the capture session. It is OK to set the filter while the Capture Session is capturing. This method expects the netmask (below) to be an jND_BYTE1 array. For details on filter strings, see the documentation of capture filters for tcpdump.

Parameters:
filterStr - a char string describing the filter. using the syntax for tcpdump.
optimize - should the filter be optimized of not?
inmask - the netmask used by the filter. Some filter elements require this, others do not. Generally, those that involve IP addresses are those that use this netmask. NOTE: The netmask for a nic can be obtained from the associated jND_NIC object.

start

public void start()
Starts capturing packets. The capture proceeds in a separate thread. As packets arrive, they are placed in a packet queue (jND_PacketQueue) which may be obtained via the packetQueue method. Packets may be retrieved from this queue.

getDelayedStop

public boolean getDelayedStop()
Get delayed stop state. If we stop a capture when the capture thread is runing, this is actually delayed until a SECOND stop, called from the thread, when it completes.

stop

public void stop()
Stops capturing packets. This actually closes the session, then reopens it, as this is a sure fire way to cancel a waiting capture call. This is less drastic than dispose, as the packet queue remains intact and the session is reopened after being closed.
